personally.

If you don't train your engineers, someone else will and you end up with a random set of skills which need individual gap filler training, instead of educating through a curriculum where students can help each other and improve the training for the next. #hiring https://t.co/flRQAmMF7G

"Throw out the term 'Testing Phase'!"
@janetgregory and @lisacrispin want everyone in a team to become a quality advocate, because it requires an entire teams knowledge to build great products, not just a dedicated role.
We all can learn to be that!
#EuroTestConf https://t.co/IjH8okvphA
Oh, Janet's Twitter handle is wrong on the slides: @janetgregoryca is correct!

Learning about Pact over beers.
#EuroTestConf https://t.co/BxMlor4H2O
@mirjam_diala @ConfBuddy https://t.co/rVjP79T2LN

I think we can summarize tonights #EuroTestConf discussion we had with:

Do more of everything,
do less of your thing.

Very excited to share the next days with a group of people who care for quality in software! It's all about #humans, #testing, #innovation, #collaboration and more.
#EuroTestConf is on! https://t.co/y2juzWaG6N
A premiere at #EuroTestConf: @mirjam_diala is giving her first keynote and shares her love for test-driven development (and dogs). https://t.co/OKDeAnfhIH

#TDD is very rewarding for humans, the cycle of breaking down a big problem into very small steps and getting them implemented leads to correct software ... and happy developers! üß†üç¨üéâ
-- @mirjam_diala at #EuroTestConf https://t.co/rfQXYmzyX1

Don't forget to refactor your tests as well, they are code too!

@mirjam_diala's way to explain #TDD is really amazing and extra kudos for the way she effortlessly uses plain language to introduce the important concepts. #EuroTestConf https://t.co/j1OgviaCTP
What @mirjam_diala thinks #tdd is about: #EuroTestConf https://t.co/YngKCTHMQ3
Learning about contract testing with pact from @nelisboucke and @matteo_pierro at #EuroTestConf https://t.co/qxdbLQYp7E
In the #EuroTestConf with @lisacrispin and @janetgregoryca to learn how to create a shared understanding in your team using frameworks like the 7 dimensions of quality. https://t.co/WjTPObRmK3

Getting some really useful tools explained hands-on in this workshop by @lisacrispin and @janetgregoryca: they to uncover many hidden assumptions that you wouldn't have thought exist!
#EuroTestConf https://t.co/28Urhj5piL

The technique is explained in the book "Discover to Deliver" (and in this post):
https://t.co/rmWnlipvyS

How to prepare for handling security incidents: 
-- @pati_gallardo at #EuroTestConf https://t.co/IS7IoXQeUm

"Developers are constantly making new things and annoy everybody else.

But remember, that's why we get paid."

Great sentiment from @pati_gallardo who encourages us to care more for the respectively *other* profession. 

#EuroTestConf

Now in the hands-on workshop with @bernardobridge on pact.
#EuroTestConf https://t.co/0to1nlFqD5

Really amazingly packed talk full of concrete advice on security best practices and how to make security an integral part of your development pipeline. I highly recommend to check out @pati_gallardo slides, and if you get the chance go see this talk!

Really excited to learn from @CrystalMbanefo about different ways of giving and receiving feedback!
#EuroTestConf https://t.co/wfWmFXyZH1

Whenever we give feedback we trigger these emotional needs:
#EuroTestConf https://t.co/OYuHWF9D4i

It's important to create a safe environment where feedback can be given without fear. Being able to receiving critical feedback with an open mind is key.
@CrystalMbanefo #EuroTestConf https://t.co/KdKinHXWiE

What about feedback for teammates and peers? @CrystalMbanefo dives into non-violent communication as a tool for changing ones mindsets to enable more honest and productive discussions in situations of conflict.
#EuroTestConf https://t.co/Qwv0DUs1FU

Here is concrete example:
@CrystalMbanefo #EuroTestConf https://t.co/QMU7g02WM4

Sometimes this will not work, and the invitation / request will be denied.
@CrystalMbanefo deals with these kinds of situations by reflecting and adapting her own needs. 
It's our responsibility to fulfill our needs, not someone else's.
#EuroTestConf https://t.co/djGGkQmXv6

Re: salaryY
It's sad that very few companies see it as an opportunity like @buffer for to be transparent about their pay: https://t.co/xw4YDb6v50
After all it's a component of the overall package, keeping it secret leads to mistrust and unfair advantage for privileged candidates.
Your employer cannot forbid you to talk about your salary. Such contract clauses are illegal.
It reduces a lot of friction during reviews if you as a company have a clear salary ladder. Employees can even review their own progress regarding their next step.
The big staffing companies compile yearly salary overviews, which is a great source for understanding current market rates.

@Mandy_Kerr When presented with obscure demands like this, I will ask for them how we can measure after a given time whether this change improved the situation.

There is no single reason in there why a #blockchain is the best solution for integrating known and trusted parties, who individually have the power to authenticate transactions: https://t.co/tA7SiKp3JF

Reading this I wonder if #blockchain was used here to sell consultancy work, but not for the benefit of the project.

Also they can't put ticket holder data on the blockchain, so I'm highly sceptical to some of the claims for speed and cost savings made in the document.

In case you need to visualize the signal strength of @NordicTweets #cellulariot chip #nrf9160 you might like this configurable #react component, which has logic to represent DBM and RSRP values:

@dc7590 Transparency of what and to which extend?

Transparency for EVERYONE, or just between trusted parties? Both can be achieved with traditional approaches (API, OpenData), it's not an exclusive feature of Blockchain.

@1ts_me_cc Yes, basically all tech companies located in Scandinavia have English as a working language, and the local language is not a requirement. But it's very much appreciated if you learn some Norwegian, Swedish, Danish, ... but for Germans that is rather easy.

@1ts_me_cc You will find many job ads written in English, which is a clear sign, but you will also often be able to apply without speaking it for tech roles. Just ask, it's a very informal culture here.

@1ts_me_cc However, for non-tech roles the story is very different, good spoken Norwegian is required, and that's hard because of strong accents. It typically takes 3 years to be fluent enough for these jobs. But I guess this is not relevant for you.
@1ts_me_cc I'm happy to jump in a video call and tell a little bit more about how work here in Trondheim @NordicTweets is for a German.

@1ts_me_cc Yes, definitely.
That's the difference, when your language works in a densly populated region (DACH, ~100 million ppl)...
@1ts_me_cc @NordicTweets Cool, PN me with some times that work for you.
@Lazer https://t.co/ouEdafeRf7

@RealIvanSanchez @NordicTweets I agree that the device should send the raw GPS data (which we do in newer examples like in the cat tracker firmware), and leave unnecessary computation to the cloud. I am pushing for this internally every day, but it's not easy to convince everyone why this is a bad idea.

@RealIvanSanchez @NordicTweets AFAIR the decision to send NMEA dates two years back when we were sending SIMULATED data from the device, not using the GPS, so there was no raw GPS data to begin with.
In presence of higher priorities and simplicity in the SDK it was kept as is when using the real GPS sensor.

@RealIvanSanchez @NordicTweets @internetofshit I appreciate that you took to time and energy to point this out.
It encourages me to keep pushing for ultra low power solutions on all layers.
